data.comment: Nice job — he really knows what to do with this project. He was able to fix everything that needed attention. Like in *philo*, he always keeps working on improvements, even from the start. His program didn’t exit immediately when a philosopher died; it continued processing the remaining actions like eating or sleeping until completion, but he managed to fix that properly. I also noticed his Makefile uses `gcc` instead of `cc`. I know that’s a Norm issue, but I didn’t want to fail him or make it look like I was doing it on purpose. Overall, as I said, he knows exactly what needs to be done for this project.
data.feedback: very good and deep evaluation, Thank you.

data.comment: That was a good piece of work and overall a very good job. He clearly understands how the project is supposed to be approached and how to organize the different requirements in order to reach a working solution. The logic for handling the map input and rendering the structure is implemented in a way that demonstrates real comprehension of the subject’s core ideas. However, there is still a visible limitation: at the moment the code only manages a single space correctly and does not properly deal with additional spacing or irregular spacing in the input. Another point that stands out is the missing support for the color codes. According to the subject, maps may contain optional hexadecimal color values (for example ,0xFFFFFF), and this part of the specification has not been implemented in his solution. I also checked the subject text again and it is true that it can be a bit confusing, since color support is mentioned but not emphasized as a mandatory requirement in every case. In practice, though, evaluators usually expect the project to handle it. Despite these missing features, the result still fulfills the main requirements and shows the project can be finished

data.comment:
Overall, solid work and a good understanding of the codebase. However, there are a few issues that need attention:
There is a memory leak when handling redirections involving heredoc. or when using something like > > with space between
The signal handling for heredoc is not fully correct — pressing Ctrl+C causes the entire minishell to exit, which shouldn't happen.
Some edge cases with the export command are not handled properly, such as running export x (without an =), which should be managed according to shell standards.
data.feedback:
I dont even know where to start. You began by testing our Minishell with a few small cases, but then immediately switched to running a tester. It felt like you werent really interested in our project itself. I made sure to let you know that I wasnt okay with you just relying on a tester to find cases where our Minishell breaks. In my opinion, thats not the right way to conduct an evaluation. It comes across as disrespectful to the effort we put into the project and also a bit lazy.

After that, we did try to fix the mistakes you pointed out, but given the size of the project, we werent able to find the solution before you moved on to the next evaluation. Maybe take this as a push to think about the way you approach evaluations in the future.

data.comment:
Great job, well done, and keep up the good work! For smaller projects, it is usually recommended to separate the bonus part from the mandatory one, but for this project it is acceptable that you did not. Nevertheless, I strongly recommend learning how to add modularized solutions or features by reusing existing code — this is exactly why the subject requires the bonus part to be separated.

Your Minishell is very well implemented and shows Bash-like behavior. For example, after unsetting PATH and running cd /bin/, the shell was still able to find the commands located in /bin. However, as you demonstrated, your Minishell requires a PATH variable to function correctly, so adding it again with export PATH=/bin/ solved the issue. Another test we performed was echo "X"$HOME'x'. Here, we had to insert a space between each argument, after which it worked exactly like in Bash.

Overall, the shell is very close to Bash behavior, while still not being Bash itself — which is perfectly fine and expected. Congratulations on passing your first Minishell evaluation, and I wish you the best of luck for the upcoming ones!
data.feedback: We had a nice Talk about how to correctly implement the Bonus in the makefile. He tested various Edge cases and tried to find some mistakes. There was a small mistake with a newline not being printed but this was a quick fix. Thanks for your time and the eval

When evaluating a project, please follow these essential rules to ensure fairness and
maintain a positive learning environment:

1. **Maintain Respect and Constructiveness**
- Be polite, courteous and respectful during the 
  evaluation process. The well-being of the community depends on it.
- Constructive feedback helps your peers improve. The well-being of 
  the community depends on a supportive approach.

2. **Identify and Discuss Issues**
- Work with the student or group to identify potential issues in their project.
  Take the time to discuss and debate any problems you find.

3. **Acknowledge Different Approaches**
- Recognize that different students may have different interpretations of the
  project’s instructions and requirements.
- Keep an open mind and grade as honestly and fairly as possible.
- The effectiveness of peer evaluation depends on serious and thoughtful assessment.

4. **Handling Incorrect Exercises**
- If you encounter an incorrect exercise, stop the assessment immediately.
- Do not proceed to the next exercise if a previous one is incorrect.
- Use the appropriate flags to report the issue and provide feedback to the student.
scale.guidelines_md:
- Only grade the work that was turned in the Git repository of the evaluated 
  student or group.

- Double-check that the Git repository belongs to the student(s). Ensure that 
  the project is the one expected. Also, check that 'git clone' is used in an 
  empty folder.

- Check carefully that no malicious aliases were used to fool you and make you 
  evaluate something that is not the content of the official repository.

- To avoid any surprises and if applicable, review together any scripts used 
  to facilitate the grading (scripts for testing or automation).

- Do not blindly trust any scripts. The tester could be wrong!

- Check the makefile: no wildcard, no relink, or the final grade is 0.

- Use make, then make --debug to be sure.

- If you have not completed the assignment you are going to evaluate, you have 
  to read the entire subject prior to starting the evaluation process.

- Use the available flags to report an empty repository, a non-functioning 
  program, a Norm error, cheating, and so forth. 
  In these cases, the evaluation process ends and the final grade is 0, 
  or -42 in case of cheating. However, except for cheating, students are 
  strongly encouraged to review together the work that was turned in, in order 
  to identify any mistakes that shouldn't be repeated in the future.

- You should never have to edit any file except the configuration file if it 
  exists. If you want to edit a file, take the time to explicit the reasons 
  with the evaluated student and make sure both of you are okay with this.

- You must also verify the absence of memory leaks. Any memory allocated on 
  the heap must be properly freed before the end of execution. 
  You are allowed to use any of the different tools available on the computer, 
  such as leaks, valgrind, or e_fence. In case of memory leaks, tick the 
  appropriate flag.

feedbacks.comment: Rigorous and thoroughly go through my code. Thanks!

data.comment: That was a really tough evaluation. Surprisingly, it made me start to enjoy the Pipex project, even though I’ve still done nothing for it yet. You’re doing an excellent job, but unfortunately, there are still some issues that need to be addressed. We’ve been doing double evaluations, each taking about two hours, and I feel bad that I can’t offer much help or advice. Still, great effort — I truly believe you can fix it, especially the FD leaks. Florian (fbraune) and I have been doing the evaluations together. ^ ^
data.feedback: An extremely thorough evaluation which exposed some file descriptor leaks which I was not aware of. I need to add more features to the parsing.

  the community depends on a supportive approach.

  Take the time to discuss and debate any problems you find.

  project’s instructions and requirements.
- Keep an open mind and grade as honestly and fairly as possible.
- The effectiveness of peer evaluation depends on serious and thoughtful assessment.

- If you encounter an incorrect exercise, stop the assessment immediately.
- Do not proceed to the next exercise if a previous one is incorrect.
- Use the appropriate flags to report the issue and provide feedback to the student.

scale.introduction_md:
When evaluating a project, please follow these essential rules to ensure fairness and
maintain a positive learning environment:

1. **Maintain Respect and Constructiveness**
- Be polite, courteous and respectful during the 
  evaluation process. The well-being of the community depends on it.
- Constructive feedback helps your peers improve. The well-being of 
  the community depends on a supportive approach.

2. **Identify and Discuss Issues**
- Work with the student or group to identify potential issues in their project.
  Take the time to discuss and debate any problems you find.

3. **Acknowledge Different Approaches**
- Recognize that different students may have different interpretations of the
  project’s instructions and requirements.
- Keep an open mind and grade as honestly and fairly as possible.
- The effectiveness of peer evaluation depends on serious and thoughtful assessment.

4. **Handling Incorrect Exercises**
- If you encounter an incorrect exercise, stop the assessment immediately.
- Do not proceed to the next exercise if a previous one is incorrect.
- Use the appropriate flags to report the issue and provide feedback to the student.
scale.guidelines_md:

  student or group.

  the project is the one expected. Also, check that 'git clone' is used in an 
  empty folder.

- Check carefully that no malicious aliases were used to fool you and make you 
  evaluate something that is not the content of the official repository.

- To avoid any surprises and if applicable, review together any scripts used 
  to facilitate the grading (scripts for testing or automation).

- Do not blindly trust any scripts. The tester could be wrong!

- Check the makefile: no wildcard, no relink, or the final grade is 0.

- Use make, then make --debug to be sure.

- If you have not completed the assignment you are going to evaluate, you have 
  to read the entire subject prior to starting the evaluation process.

- Use the available flags to report an empty repository, a non-functioning 
  program, a Norm error, cheating, and so forth.

  or -42 in case of cheating. However, except for cheating, students are

- You must also verify the absence of memory leaks. Any memory allocated on 
  the heap must be properly freed before the end of execution.

scale.name: scale 6.4 1749137067 gojqciwra
scale.introduction_md:
Please adhere to the following rules during the evaluation process:

 - Always remain polite, courteous, respectful, and constructive.
   The well-being of the community depends on it.

 - Work with the evaluated person (or group) to identify any potential
   issues in their work.
   Take the time to discuss and debate the problems you’ve found.

 - Keep in mind that your peers may have interpreted the project’s
   instructions and scope differently.
   Stay open-minded and grade them as honestly as possible.

 - The educational value of this process relies entirely on serious and
   fair peer evaluations.
scale.guidelines_md:
- Only grade the work that is in the student's or group's Git repository.

- Double-check that the Git repository belongs to the student or group.
  Ensure the work is for the relevant project and verify that "git clone"
  is used in an empty folder.

- Carefully check that no malicious aliases have been used to mislead
  you into evaluating something other than the official repository's
  content.

- To avoid surprises, both the evaluating and evaluated students must 
  review any scripts used to facilitate grading.

- If the evaluating student has not yet completed the project, they
  must read the entire subject before starting the defense.

- Use the flags available on the scale to signal issues such as an
  empty repository, a non-functioning program, norm errors, or cheating.
  In these cases, the grading ends immediately, and the final grade
  is 0 (-42 in case of cheating).

 - However, except for cases of cheating, you are encouraged to discuss
  the work, even if incomplete, to help identify issues and avoid
  repeating mistakes.

- During the defense, no segmentation faults (segfaults), unexpected
  crashes, or uncontrolled terminations are allowed.
  If any occur, the final grade is 0, and you must use the appropriate flag.

- You should never edit any file except for a configuration file (if it exists).
  If editing a file is necessary, discuss the reasons with the evaluated
  student and ensure both agree before proceeding.

- Verify that only the requested files are present in the Git repository.
  If additional files are found, the evaluation stops immediately.

data.comment:
the team solved this difficult task. the parsing part was very thorough, all functions made sense in terms of their purpose and naming. i could see the team's effort and determination throughout the project. also, good job with git! everyone contributed to the repo. they passed all the tester cases which is really impressive. they also learned about new useful concepts like backtracking and argc/argv.

we used the time to talk about malloc and free. i suggest you read about them a bit more and, of course, practice practice practice ( ◡‿◡ )  when using malloc, remember about malloc protection to see if memory actually was allocated + always free and set pointer to NULL. to check for memory leaks, try googling "valgrind" (if you're really determined) or "system leaks" (would be enough for now).

register for the next rush! i think you made a great team and you should be proud of yourselves <(￣︶￣)>
data.feedback: Thanks a lot for your feedback. I learned some new things :)
